A COMMERCIAL air transport flight is planned from northern Europe to the island of Tenerife via T16 airway to benefit from stronger tailwinds. One of the FMS is inoperative. The aeroplane is following the route across the NORTH SEA and an attempt to reset the FMS is not successful. What implications, if any, are there for the continuation of the flight?

options.text: The pilots must avoid NAT HLA since entry to NAT HLA is forbidden with only one serviceable LRNS.
The pilots must request a reroute via T290 or T9 since the aeroplane has only one serviceable LRNS.
The aircraft should return to the departure aerodrome as flight with only one FMS means that NO redundancy exists and is forbidden.
Airway T16 may be used as planned since the aeroplane maintains Its navigation capability with the remaining FMS.

variant.question: During a flight, the captain is informed that a passenger is using a portable electronic device, which is adversely affecting the aircraft's electrical avionics. What shall the captain do?

options.text: He/she may allow the device to be used except during take-off and landing.
He/she may allow the device to be used at take-off and landing.
He/she may allow the device to be used with certain exceptions.
He/she must stop the passenger from using the device.

variant.question: During a night flight, an observer located in the cockpit, seeing an aircraft coming from front left on approximate opposite parallel track, will first see the:
